subject: RE: [junit] Websphere Connection Pool
msgSnippet: ... In this case the test *was* the database connection. I try to minimize the number of tests that hit the database, but I ve done enough inserts to and reads
messageBody:
On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:

> One thing I don't think we ever discussed is the fact that, in the
> case we were discussing, the mock object approach allows you to
> separate your test from the database connection.

In this case the test *was* the database connection.

I try to minimize the number of tests that hit the database, but I've
done enough inserts to and reads from the wrong columns that I try to
test each SQL statement I execute.

And then generally I create mock versions of those objects that actually
do database work so that I can test everything else without touching the
database.

So it sounds like we're on the same page here.

> Ha, ha. Again, we are discussing general principles and you retreat to
> the particular case. Yes, two lines in this case. But I am trying to
> analyze the strategy via the example, not just this example.

Being an XP-kinda-guy, I don't bother analyzing before hand. I just do
what seems easiest, and fix it later if circumstances change.

If I were adding a five-line method every time, and I had fifty of them,
there's quite a good probably I'd switch to some sort of mock object for
the connection pool.

> I'm interested in making explicit the thinking that guides
> testability. What is "testability?" And what is "maintainability?"

I usually find the best way to explore these things is to do a lot of
examples, and then generalize them.
